title: Do Legislatures Enhance Democracy in Africa?
descriptions:
Abstract:

The Role of African Legislatures in Electoral Authoritarian Regimes: A Comparative Study. This project aims to shed light on the democratic potential of legislatures in African authoritarian regimes, a topic of ongoing debate among scholars. Some argue that the presence of a national assembly and multiparty system reinforces autocratic rule, while others contend that repeated multiparty elections pave the way for democratic development. To address this question, our research will collect data on legislatures in seven African countries, examining three key areas: law-making, inter-party interactions, and constituency representation. Using a mixed-methods approach combining qualitative and quantitative data, we will conduct content analysis of parliamentary debates and full population surveys of national assembly members to gather biographical, opinion, and social interaction data. Social Network Analysis and process tracing will be employed to identify causal mechanisms between legislative behavior and democratic outcomes. Our research, conducted in partnership with institutions in seven African countries, will provide the first systematic and comprehensive empirical evidence on legislative behavior in electoral autocracies, filling a critical gap in the existing literature and contributing to a deeper understanding of the democratic potential of African legislatures.

**Description:**

Do Legislatures Enhance Democracy in Africa? This project seeks to investigate the role of legislatures in African electoral authoritarian regimes. There are two opposing theoretical views: While several studies have found that holding elections, introducing a national assembly and a multiparty system prolongs the life of autocracies, other authors claim the exact opposite: in their view, the more successive multiparty elections take place, the more democratic a regime becomes. Answering these questions is difficult due to the opaqueness of authoritarian regimes. Moreover, most work has concentrated on only a few cases â€“ African cases, in particular, have remained largely absent from the research agenda. This project attempts to fill these gaps by collecting data on authoritarian legislatures in seven African countries. We focus on three areas of investigation: 1) law-making; 2) interaction patterns and political dialogue between the ruling party and the opposition; and 3) representation and constituency responsiveness. The main question is whether legislatures in authoritarian countries actually have a potential to enhance democracy. We use a Mixed Methods-Design which combines qualitative and quantitative data. To answer Question 1, we use content analysis of parliamentary debates. For Question 2 and 3, we will conduct full population surveys in the national assemblies of our seven countries. We will collect biographical and opinion data, as well as data on the social interactions between government and opposition, which will be analyzed with the methods of Social Network Analysis. Furthermore, we employ process tracing to understand the causal mechanism between legislative behaviour and the level of democracy. With a strong team of partner institutions in seven African countries, this project fills a research gap by collecting extensive and systematic empirical evidence on legislative behaviour in electoral autocracies for the first time.
